revision.text:
{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Gougerot–Blum syndrome | synonyms = | image = | caption = | pronounce = | field = dermatology | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Gougerot–Blum syndrome''' (also known as "'''pigmented purpuric lichenoid dermatitis'''",<ref name="Bolognia">{{cite book |author=Rapini, Ronald P. |author2=Bolognia, Jean L. |author3=Jorizzo, Joseph L. |title=Dermatology: 2-Volume Set |publisher=Mosby |location=St. Louis |year=2007 |pages= |isbn=1-4160-2999-0 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref> and "'''pigmented purpuric lichenoid dermatitis of Gougerot and Blum'''"<ref name="Bolognia" />) is a variant of [[pigmented purpuric dermatosis|pigmented purpuric dermatitis]], a skin condition characterized by minute, rust-colored to violaceous, lichenoid [[papule]]s that tend to fuse into plaques of various hues.<ref name="Andrews">{{cite book |author=James, William D. |author2=Berger, Timothy G.|title=Andrews' Diseases of the Skin: clinical Dermatology |publisher=Saunders Elsevier |location= |year=2006 |pages= |isbn=0-7216-2921-0 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=|display-authors=etal}}</ref>{{rp|829}} Relative to other variants, it is characterized clinically by a male predominance, pruritus, with a predilection for the legs, and histologically, it features a densely cellular lichenoid infiltrate.<ref>Barnhill RL and Crowson AN (eds) Textbook of Dermatopathology, second edition, McGraw-Hill, 2004: 211-212</ref>
It was characterized in 1925.<ref>{{WhoNamedIt|synd|2079}}</ref>
Gougerot–Blum syndrome is named after the French dermatologists [[Henri Gougerot]] (1881–1955) and [[Paul Blum]] (1878–1933).
== See also == * [[Pigmentary purpuric eruptions]] * [[Skin lesion]] * [[List of cutaneous conditions]]

[[Image:Chrom(VI)-oxid.jpg|thumb|An example of a chromium(VI) compound: [[chromium trioxide]]]] '''Hexavalent chromium''' ('''chromium(VI)''', '''Cr(VI)''', '''chromium 6''') is any [[chemical compound]] that contains the element [[chromium]] in the +6 [[oxidation state]] (thus [[valence (chemistry)#Common valences|hexavalent]]). Virtually all chromium ore is processed via hexavalent chromium, specifically the [[salt (chemistry)|salt]] [[sodium dichromate]]. Approximately {{convert|136000|tonne|lb}} of hexavalent chromium were produced in 1985.<ref name=Ullmann>Gerd Anger, Jost Halstenberg, Klaus Hochgeschwender, Christoph Scherhag, Ulrich Korallus, Herbert Knopf, Peter Schmidt, Manfred Ohlinger, "Chromium Compounds" in ''Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry'', Wiley-VCH, Weinheim, 2005. {{DOI|10.1002/14356007.a07_067}}</ref> Additional hexavalent chromium compounds are [[chromium trioxide]] and various salts of [[chromate and dichromate]], among others. Hexavalent chromium is used in textile dyes, wood preservation, [[anti-corrosion]] products, [[chromate conversion coating]]s, and a variety of niche uses. Industrial uses of hexavalent chromium compounds include chromate pigments in dyes, paints, inks, and plastics; chromates added as anticorrosive agents to paints, primers, and other surface coatings; and [[chromic acid]] [[electroplate]]d onto metal parts to provide a decorative or protective coating. Hexavalent chromium can be formed when performing "hot work" such as welding on stainless steel or melting chromium metal. In these situations the chromium is not originally hexavalent, but the high temperatures involved in the process result in oxidation that converts the chromium to a hexavalent state.<ref name=":2">29 [[Code of Federal Regulations|CFR]] OSHA General Industry 1910</ref> Hexavalent chromium can also be found in drinking water and public water systems.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Xie|first=Yun|last2=Holmgren|first2=Stephanie|last3=Andrews|first3=Danica M. K.|last4=Wolfe|first4=Mary S.|title=Evaluating the Impact of the U.S. National Toxicology Program: A Case Study on Hexavalent Chromium|url=http://ehp.niehs.nih.gov/EHP21|journal=Environmental Health Perspectives|volume=125|issue=2|pages=181–188|doi=10.1289/ehp21|pmid=27483499|pmc=5289905|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027192352/http://ehp.niehs.nih.gov/EHP21/|archivedate=2016-10-27|df=|year=2017}}</ref>
Inhaled hexavalent chromium is recognized as a human [[carcinogen]].<ref name=book>{{cite book |author = IARC |authorlink = International Agency for Research on Cancer |title = Volume 49: Chromium, Nickel, and Welding |origyear = 1990 |url = http://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Monographs/vol49/volume49.pdf |format = PDF |accessdate = 2006-07-16 |date = 1999-11-05 |isbn = 978-92-832-1249-2 |quote = There is ''sufficient evidence'' in humans for the carcinogenicity of chromium[VI] compounds as encountered in the chromate production, chromate pigment production and chromium plating industries. |publisher = International Agency for Research on Cancer |location = Lyon |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081224153750/http://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Monographs/vol49/volume49.pdf |archivedate = 2008-12-24 |df = }}</ref> Workers in many occupations are exposed to hexavalent chromium. Problematic exposure is known to occur among workers who handle chromate-containing products and those who grind and/ or weld stainless steel.<ref name=book/> Workers who are exposed to hexavalent chromium are at increased risk of developing lung cancer, asthma, or damage to the nasal epithelia and skin.<ref name=":2" /> Within the [[European Union]], the use of hexavalent chromium in electronic equipment is largely prohibited by the [[Restriction of Hazardous Substances Directive]].
==Toxicity==
Hexavalent chromium compounds are [[Genotoxicity|genotoxic]] [[carcinogen]]s. Due to its structural similarity to sulfate, chromate (a typical form of chromium(VI) at neutral pH) is transported into cells via [[sulfate]] channels.<ref name="Salnikow">{{cite journal|last2=Zhitkovich|first2=A.|year=2008|title=Genetic and Epigenetic Mechanisms in Metal Carcinogenesis and Cocarcinogenesis: Nickel, Arsenic, and Chromium|url=|journal=Chem. Res. Toxicol|volume=21|issue=1|pages=28–44|doi=10.1021/tx700198a|pmc=2602826|pmid=17970581|last1=Salnikow|first1=K.}}</ref> Inside the cell, hexavalent chromium (chromium(VI)) is reduced first to pentavalent chromium (chromium(V)) then to trivalent chromium (chromium(III)) without the aid of any enzymes.<ref name="Salnikow" /><ref name="Shi">{{cite journal|last2=Mao|first2=Y.|last3=Knapton|first3=A.D.|year=1994|title=Reaction of Cr(VI) with ascorbate and hydrogen peroxide generates hydroxyl radicals and causes dnA damage: role of a Cr(IV)-mediated Fenton-like reaction|url=|journal=Carcinogenesis|volume=15|issue=11|pages=2475–2478|doi=10.1093/carcin/15.11.2475|pmid=7955094|last1=Shi|first1=X.|display-authors=etal}}</ref> The reduction occurs via direct electron transfer primarily from [[ascorbate]] and some nonprotein [[thiol]]s.<ref name="Salnikow" /> [[Vitamin C]] and other [[reducing agent]]s combine with chromate to give chromium(III) products inside the cell.<ref name="Salnikow" /> The resultant chromium(III) forms stable complexes with [[nucleic acid]]s and [[protein]]s.<ref name="Salnikow" /> This causes strand breaks and Cr-DNA adducts which are responsible for mutagenic damage.<ref name="Salnikow" /> According to Shi et al., the DNA can also be damaged by [[hydroxyl radical]]s produced during reoxidation of pentavalent chromium by [[hydrogen peroxide]] molecules present in the cell, which can cause double-strand breakage.<ref name="Shi" />
Both insoluble salts of lead and barium chromates as well as soluble chromates were negative in the implantation model of lung [[carcinogenesis]].<ref name="Salnikow" /> Yet, soluble chromates are a confirmed [[carcinogen]] so it would be prudent to consider all chromates carcinogenic.<ref name="Salnikow" />
Chronic inhalation from occupational exposures increases the risk of respiratory cancers.<ref name="Salnikow" /> The most common form of lung [[Cancer|malignancies]] in chromate workers is squamous cell carcinoma.<ref name="Salnikow" /> Ingestion of chromium(VI) through drinking water has been found to cause cancer in the [[oral cavity]] and [[small intestine]].<ref name="Salnikow" /> It can also cause irritation or ulcers in the stomach and intestines, and toxicity in the liver.<ref name="Salnikow" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/region07/pdf/national_beef_leathers-prime_tanning_chromiumVI_Fact_Sheet.pdf |title=Facts About Chromium |last= |first= |date=April 13, 2013 |website=[[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] |publisher= |access-date=July 13, 2016 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130413124953/http://www.epa.gov/region07/pdf/national_beef_leathers-prime_tanning_chromiumVI_Fact_Sheet.pdf |archivedate=April 13, 2013 |df= }}</ref> Liver toxicity shows the body’s apparent inability to detoxify chromium(VI) in the GI tract where it can then enter the circulatory system.<ref name="Salnikow" />
Of 2,345 unsafe products in 2015 listed by the [[Věra Jourová|EU Commission for Justice, Consumers and Gender Equality]] some 64% came from China, and 23% were clothing articles, including leather goods (and shoes) contaminated with hexavalent chromium.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.eaccny.com/news/chapternews/keeping-consumers-safe-nearly-2500-dangerous-products-withdrawn-from-the-eu-market-in-2014/|title=Keeping consumers safe: nearly 2500 dangerous products withdrawn from the EU market in 2014 {{!}} European American Chamber of Commerce New York [EACCNY] {{!}} Your Partner for Transatlantic Business Resources|website=www.eaccny.com|access-date=2016-10-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027123101/https://www.eaccny.com/news/chapternews/keeping-consumers-safe-nearly-2500-dangerous-products-withdrawn-from-the-eu-market-in-2014/|archivedate=2016-10-27|df=}}</ref> Chromate-dyed textiles or chromate-tanned leather shoes can cause skin sensitivity.<ref name=":3" />
In the U.S., the [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration|OSHA]] [[Permissible exposure limit|PEL]] for airborne exposures to hexavalent chromium is 5 µg/m<sup>3</sup> (0.005 mg/m<sup>3</sup>).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.osha.gov/Publications/OSHA_small_entity_comp.pdf |title=OSHA: Small Entity Compliance Guide for the Hexavalent Chromium Standards |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-12-05 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018045036/http://www.osha.gov/Publications/OSHA_small_entity_comp.pdf |archivedate=2012-10-18 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = David Blowes | title = Tracking Hexavalent Cr in Groundwater | journal = [[Science (journal)|Science]] | volume = 295 | pages = 2024–25 | year = 2002 | doi = 10.1126/science.1070031 | pmid = 11896259 | issue = 5562}}</ref> The U.S. [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health]] proposed a [[Recommended exposure limit|REL]] of 0.2 µg/m<sup>3</sup> for airborne exposures to hexavalent chromium.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/docs/2013-128/pdfs/2013_128.pdf|title=Criteria for a Recommended Standard: Occupational Exposure to Hexavalent Chromium|last=[[National Institute for Occupational Health and Safety]]|first=|date=September 2013|website=|publisher=|format=PDF|access-date=|accessdate=2013-12-05|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516064228/http://www.cdc.gov/niosh/docs/2013-128/pdfs/2013_128.pdf|archivedate=2013-05-16|df=}}</ref>
For drinking water the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) does not have a [[Maximum Contaminant Level]] (MCL) for hexavalent chromium. California has finalized a Public Health Goal of 0.02 parts per billion ([[Parts per Billion|ppb]] or micrograms per liter)<ref name="Hexavalent Chromium PHG">{{cite web |url=http://www.oehha.org/water/phg/072911Cr6PHG.html |title=Hexavalent Chromium PHG |publisher=Oehha.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-05 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106174933/http://www.oehha.org/water/phg/072911Cr6PHG.html |archivedate=2014-01-06 |df= }}</ref> and established a MCL of 10 ppb.<ref name="HEX Chrome Letter">{{cite web |url=http://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/documents/chromium6/LettertoPWS-StateAdoptionofaHexavalentChromiumMCL-20140620.pdf |title=State Adoption of a Hexavalent Chromium MCL |accessdate=2014-10-08 |publisher=California Department of Public Health |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141013225132/http://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/documents/chromium6/LettertoPWS-StateAdoptionofaHexavalentChromiumMCL-20140620.pdf |archivedate=2014-10-13 |df= }}</ref>
== Remediation of hexavalent chromium in groundwater and drinking water == There are mainly three types of methods to remediate hexavalent chromium in ground water and drinking water: 1) reduction of toxicity, 2) removal technologies and 3) containment technologies.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://engr.uconn.edu/~baholmen/docs/ENVE290W/National%20Chromium%20Files%20From%20Luke/Cr(VI)%20Handbook/L1608_C08.pdf|title=Chromium (VI) Handbook|publisher=CRC Press|year=2004|isbn=9781566706087|location=United States of America|pages=280–298|quote=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170110203935/http://engr.uconn.edu/~baholmen/docs/ENVE290W/National%20Chromium%20Files%20From%20Luke/Cr(VI)%20Handbook/L1608_C08.pdf|archivedate=2017-01-10|df=}}</ref> Reduction of toxicity of hexavalent chromium involves methods using chemicals, microbes and plants. Some removal technologies include transporting contaminated soil offsite to a landfill, using ion exchange resins to reduce chromium(VI) concentrations to less than detectable limit and granular [[activated carbon]] (GAC) filter. Containment technologies can be employed with the use of physical barriers such as grouts, slurries or sheet piling.
Attempts have been made to test the removal or reduction of hexavalent chromium from aqueous solutions and environment. For example, a research study conducted by the School of Industrial Technology, [[University Sains Malaysia]] in 2010 found that [[chitosan]] coated with poly 3-methyl thiophene can be effectively employed for removal of hexavalent chromium ions from aqueous solutions. Chitosan is a very cheap, economical, and environmentally friendly substrate for coating of this polymer. Adsorption of chromium(VI) is found to be effective in the lower pH range and at higher temperatures and subsequent desorption is readily achieved upon alkaline treatment of the adsorbent.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hena|first=Sufia|date=2010-09-15|title=Removal of chromium hexavalent ion from aqueous solutions using biopolymer chitosan coated with poly 3-methyl thiophene polymer|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304389410006205|journal=Journal of Hazardous Materials|volume=181|issue=1–3|pages=474–479|doi=10.1016/j.jhazmat.2010.05.037}}</ref> Another study done by the [[American Industrial Hygiene Association]] indicates that the airborne hexavalent chromium in acidic mists of an electroplating tank collected on PVC filters was reduced over time after mist generation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shin|first=Yong Chul|last2=Paik|first2=Nam Won|date=2000-07-01|title=Reduction of Hexavalent Chromium Collected on PVC Filters|journal=AIHAJ - American Industrial Hygiene Association|volume=61|issue=4|pages=563–567|doi=10.1080/15298660008984569|issn=1529-8663}}</ref> A number of other emerging technologies for removing chromium from water are also currently under research, including the use of [[cation|cationic]] [[metal-organic frameworks]] to selectively [[adsorption|adsorb]] chromium [[oxyanions]].<ref name="Aboutorabi MOF">{{cite journal | url=https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.inorgchem.6b00522 | title=Metal-Organic Framework Based on Isonicotinate N-Oxide for Fast and Highly Efficient Aqueous Phase Cr(VI) Adsorption | author=Leila Aboutorabi et. al. | journal=Inorganic Chemistry | year=2016 | volume=55 | issue=11 | pages=5507–5513 | doi=10.1021/acs.inorgchem.6b00522 | issn=1520-510X}}</ref>
==Exposure and safety issues== Hexavalent chromium is a constituent of [[tobacco smoke]].<ref name="TalhoutSchulz2011">{{cite journal|last1=Talhout|first1=Reinskje|last2=Schulz|first2=Thomas|last3=Florek|first3=Ewa|last4=Van Benthem|first4=Jan|last5=Wester|first5=Piet|last6=Opperhuizen|first6=Antoon|title=Hazardous Compounds in Tobacco Smoke|journal=International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health|volume=8|issue=12|year=2011|pages=613–628|issn=1660-4601|doi=10.3390/ijerph8020613|pmid=21556207|pmc=3084482}}</ref> ===Australia===
====Kooragang Island, New South Wales==== Hexavalent chromium was released from the Newcastle [[Orica]] Kooragang Island [[ammonium nitrate]] plant on August 8, 2011.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.environmentaljustice.com.au/2011/08/hexavalent-chromium-leaks-from-orica-site-in-newcastle/|title=Hexavalent Chromium leaks from Orica site in Newcastle {{!}} {{!}} Environmental Justice SocietyEnvironmental Justice Society|website=www.environmentaljustice.com.au|access-date=2016-10-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027191845/http://www.environmentaljustice.com.au/2011/08/hexavalent-chromium-leaks-from-orica-site-in-newcastle/|archivedate=2016-10-27|df=}}</ref> The incident occurred when the plant entered the ‘start up’ phase after the completion of a five-yearly maintenance overhaul.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/committees/DBAssets/InquiryReport/ReportAcrobat/5816/120223%20Orica%20Report.pdf|title=Select Committee on the Kooragang Island Orica Chemical Leak|last=New South Wales Parliament|first=|date=2012|website=|publisher=|access-date=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170115194406/https://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/committees/DBAssets/InquiryReport/ReportAcrobat/5816/120223%20Orica%20Report.pdf|archivedate=2017-01-15|df=}}</ref> The “High Temperature Shift catalyst began the process of ‘reduction’” where steam passes through the catalyst bed and out the SP8 vent stack.<ref name=":5" /> At this time lower temperatures in parts of the plant caused some of the steam to condense lower which caused chromium(VI) from the catalyst bed to dissolve into the liquid present.<ref name=":5" /> The amount of condensate overwhelmed the drainage arrangements resulting in the emission of condensate through the SP8 vent stack.<ref name=":5" /> The leak went undetected for 30-minutes releasing 200 kg of chromium(VI) into the atmosphere exposing up to 20 workers at the plant and 70 nearby homes in [[Stockton, New South Wales|Stockton]].<ref name=":5" />
The town was not notified of the exposure until three days later on Wednesday morning.<ref name=":4" /> This accident sparked a major public controversy, with Orica criticized for playing down the extent and possible risks of the leak.<ref name=":6">{{cite news|url=http://www.theherald.com.au/news/local/news/general/stockton-residents-fume-over-fallout-from-orica/2256110.aspx|title=Stockton residents fume over fallout from Orica|last=Jones|first=Jackqui|date=11 August 2011|publisher=[[Newcastle Herald]]|accessdate=12 August 2011}}</ref>
The office of Environment and Heritage in Stockton collected 71 samples. Low levels of chromium were detected in 11 of them.<ref name=":4" /> These 11 samples were taken within six residential blocks close to the Orica plant, two of which were from water samples collected immediately south of the six block area.<ref name=":4" />
The Select Committee on the Kooragnang Island Orica Chemical Leak released their report on the incident in February 2012. They found Orica’s approach to addressing the leak’s impact was grossly inadequate.<ref name=":5" /> Orica failed to realize the potential impact that [[prevailing winds]] would have on an emission 60 meters high.<ref name=":5" /> Orica failed to inspect the area immediately downwind and notify the [[Office of Environment and Heritage (New South Wales)|Office of Environment and Heritage]] until August 9, 2011.<ref name=":5" /> In Orica’s initial report to the Office of Environment and Heritage they failed to disclose that the emissions had escaped off-site.<ref name=":5" /> In the initial report to [[WorkCover Authority of New South Wales|WorkCover]] Orica did not disclose potential impacts on workers as well as that the substance emitted was chromium(VI).<ref name=":5" /> Orica’s Emergency Response plan was not well understood by employees particularly about notification procedures.<ref name=":5" /> The original notification of residents in Stockton was only to households immediately downwind of the emission which failed to realize the potential for contamination of the surrounding area as well.<ref name=":5" /> The information presented at the original notification downplayed potential health risks and subsequently provided incomplete information and has led to a lack of trust between Stockton residents and Orica officials.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" />
In 2014, Orica plead guilty to nine charges before the Land and Environment court and was fined $768,000.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-07-28/company-orica-fined-over-chemical-spills-and-safety-breaches/5629974|title=Orica fined over chemical spills and breaches in NSW|date=2014-07-28|website=ABC News|language=en-AU|access-date=2016-08-20|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161016233145/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-07-28/company-orica-fined-over-chemical-spills-and-safety-breaches/5629974|archivedate=2016-10-16|df=}}</ref> NSW Health findings ruled that it is very unlikely that anyone in Stockton will develop cancer as a result of the incident.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.health.nsw.gov.au/news/Documents/orica-report.pdf|title=Release of Chromium VI from the Orica chemical plant, Kooragang Island, Stockton, 8th August 2011. Final Risk Assessment Report, 2nd September 2011|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=NSW Health|access-date=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161016215641/http://www.health.nsw.gov.au/news/Documents/orica-report.pdf|archivedate=2016-10-16|df=}}</ref>
=== Bangladesh === Toxic poultry feed contaminated by chromium-based [[leather]] [[Tanning (leather)|tanning]] (as opposed to traditional slower vegetable tanning) is entering the food supply in Bangladesh through chicken meat, which is the most common source of protein in the country. Tanneries in [[Hazaribagh Thana]], an industrial neighborhood of [[Dhaka]], emit around 21,600 cubic meters of toxic waste each day. The tanneries also generate as much as 100 tonnes per day of scraps, trimmed raw hide, flesh and fat, which are processed into feed by neighborhood recycling plants and used in chicken and fish farms across the country. Chromium levels ranging from 350 to 4,520 micrograms (0.35 to 4.52 mg) per kilogram were found in different organs of chickens which had been fed the tannery-scraps feed for two months, according to Abul Hossain, a chemistry professor at the [[University of Dhaka]]. The study estimated up to 25% of the chickens in Bangladesh contained harmful levels of chromium(VI).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/bangladesh/245/details/398475/toxic-poultry-feed-threatens-bangladesh%E2%80%99s-poor|title=Toxic poultry feed threatens Bangladesh’s poor|last=[[IRIN]]|first=|date=2014-06-30|website=[[Gulf Times]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-07-15|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140907010854/http://www.gulf-times.com/bangladesh/245/details/398475/toxic-poultry-feed-threatens-bangladesh%E2%80%99s-poor|archivedate=2014-09-07|df=}}</ref>
=== Greece ===
====Eastern Central Greece==== The chemistry of the groundwater in eastern [[Central Greece]] (central [[Euboea]] and the [[Asopos]] valley) revealed high concentrations of hexavalent chromium in groundwater systems sometimes exceeding the Greek and the EU drinking water maximum acceptable level for total chromium. Hexavalent chromium pollution here is associated with industrial waste.
By using the GFAAS for total chromium, diphenylcarbazide-Cr(VI) complex colorimetric method for hexavalent chromium, and flame-AAS and [[Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry|ICP-MS]] for other toxic elements, their concentrations were investigated in several groundwater samples. The contamination of water by hexavalent chromium in central Euboea is mainly linked to natural processes, but there are anthropogenic cases.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Geochemical Characteristics of Natural Waters Contaminated by Hexavalent Chromium, in Eastern Sterea Hellas, Greece|url=http://www.aueb.gr/users/koundouri/resees/uploads/geo2.pdf|journal=Scientific Annals|volume=99|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170115234233/http://www.aueb.gr/users/koundouri/resees/uploads/geo2.pdf|archivedate=2017-01-15|df=}}</ref>
====Thebes – Tanagra – Malakasa (Asopos) Basin==== In the [[Thebes, Greece|Thebes]] – [[Tanagra]] – [[Malakasa]] basin, Eastern [[Central Greece]],<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Charalampos|first=Vasilatos, [et al.]|date=2008|title=Hexavalent chromium and other toxic elements in natural waters in the Thiva – Tanagra – Malakasa Basin, Greece|url=http://www.hellenjgeosci.geol.uoa.gr/43/GEOL%2043%20PAGES%2057-66.pdf|journal=Hellenic Journal of Geosciences|volume=43|issue=57–56|doi=|pmid=|access-date=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130614161114/http://www.hellenjgeosci.geol.uoa.gr/43/GEOL%2043%20PAGES%2057-66.pdf|archivedate=2013-06-14|df=}}</ref> which supports many industrial activities, concentrations of chromium (up to 80 μg/L Cr(VI)) and Inofyta (up to 53 μg/L Cr(VI) were found in the urban water supply of [[Oropos]]). Chromium(VI) concentrations ranging from 5 to 33 μg/L Cr(VI) were found in groundwater that is used for [[Thebes, Greece|Thiva]]'s water supply. [[Arsenic]] concentrations up to 34 μg/L along with chromium(VI) levels up to 40 μg/L were detected in [[Schimatari]]'s water supply. In the [[Asopus|Asopos River]], total chromium values were up to 13 μg/L, hexavalent chromium was less than 5 μg/L and other toxic elements were relatively low.<ref name=":1" />
=== Iraq === In 2008, defense contractor [[KBR (company)|KBR]] was alleged to have exposed 16 members of the [[Indiana National Guard]], as well as its own workers, to hexavalent chromium at the Qarmat Ali water treatment facility in [[Iraq]] in 2003.<ref>[http://www.democracynow.org/2008/12/4/indiana_guardsmen_sue_kbr_over_chemical Indiana Guardsmen Sue KBR Over Chemical] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081205233604/http://www.democracynow.org/2008/12/4/indiana_guardsmen_sue_kbr_over_chemical |date=2008-12-05 }} from ''[[Democracy Now!]]'', December 4, 2008</ref> Later, 433 members of the [[Oregon Military Department|Oregon National Guard]]'s 162nd Infantry Battalion were informed of possible exposure to hexavalent chromium while escorting KBR contractors.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/12/us/12brfs-POSSIBLECHEM_BRF.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=Oregon%20National%20Guard&st=cse Associated Press (February 12, 2009)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170313194004/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/12/us/12brfs-POSSIBLECHEM_BRF.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=Oregon%20National%20Guard&st=cse |date=March 13, 2017 }}. "Oregon: Possible Chemical Exposure". New York Times. Retrieved on February 12, 2009.</ref> One of the National Guard soldiers, David Moore, died in February 2008. The cause was lung disease at age 42. His death was ruled service-related. His brother believes it was hexavalent chromium.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2009/06/27/dozens-national-guard-soldiers-sick-after-iraq-2003-deploy-toxic-chemical-eyed.html|title=Dozens Of National Guard Soldiers Sick After Iraq 2003 Deploy, Toxic Chemical Eyed|date=2009-06-27|newspaper=Fox News|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027124558/http://www.foxnews.com/story/2009/06/27/dozens-national-guard-soldiers-sick-after-iraq-2003-deploy-toxic-chemical-eyed.html|archivedate=2016-10-27|df=}}</ref> On November 2, 2012, a [[Portland, Oregon]] jury found KBR negligent in knowingly exposing twelve National Guard soldiers to hexavalent chromium while working at the Qarmat Ali water treatment facility and awarded damages of $85 million to the plaintiffs.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2012/11/02/justice/oregon-national-guard-lawsuit/index.html CNN (November 3, 2012)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103140721/http://www.cnn.com/2012/11/02/justice/oregon-national-guard-lawsuit/index.html |date=November 3, 2012 }}. "Defense contractor ordered to pay millions to National Guard soldiers". CNN. Retrieved on November 3, 2012.</ref>
===United States===
==== History of the EPA’s chromium policies in the United States ==== Prior to 1970, the federal government had limited reach in monitoring and enforcing environmental regulations. Local governments were tasked with environmental monitoring and regulations, such as the monitoring of heavy metals in wastewater. Examples of this can be seen in larger municipalities such Chicago, Los Angeles, and New York.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://nepis.epa.gov/Exe/ZyNET.exe/9100FMSN.TXT?ZyActionD=ZyDocument&Client=EPA&Index=1976+Thru+1980&Docs=&Query=&Time=&EndTime=&SearchMethod=1&TocRestrict=n&Toc=&TocEntry=&QField=&QFieldYear=&QFieldMonth=&QFieldDay=&IntQFieldOp=0&ExtQFieldOp=0&XmlQuery=&File=D:%5Czyfiles%5CIndex%20Data%5C76thru80%5CTxt%5C00000015%5C9100FMSN.txt&User=ANONYMOUS&Password=anonymous&SortMethod=h%7C-&MaximumDocuments=1&FuzzyDegree=0&ImageQuality=r75g8/r75g8/x150y150g16/i425&Display=hpfr&DefSeekPage=x&SearchBack=ZyActionL&Back=ZyActionS&BackDesc=Results%20page&MaximumPages=1&ZyEntry=1&SeekPage=x&ZyPURL|title=Document Display {{!}} NEPIS {{!}} US EPA|language=en|access-date=2016-10-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161028021236/https://nepis.epa.gov/Exe/ZyNET.exe/9100FMSN.TXT?ZyActionD=ZyDocument&Client=EPA&Index=1976+Thru+1980&Docs=&Query=&Time=&EndTime=&SearchMethod=1&TocRestrict=n&Toc=&TocEntry=&QField=&QFieldYear=&QFieldMonth=&QFieldDay=&IntQFieldOp=0&ExtQFieldOp=0&XmlQuery=&File=D%3A%5Czyfiles%5CIndex%20Data%5C76thru80%5CTxt%5C00000015%5C9100FMSN.txt&User=ANONYMOUS&Password=anonymous&SortMethod=h%7C-&MaximumDocuments=1&FuzzyDegree=0&ImageQuality=r75g8%2Fr75g8%2Fx150y150g16%2Fi425&Display=hpfr&DefSeekPage=x&SearchBack=ZyActionL&Back=ZyActionS&BackDesc=Results%20page&MaximumPages=1&ZyEntry=1&SeekPage=x&ZyPURL|archivedate=2016-10-28|df=}}</ref> A specific example was in 1969, the Chicago Metropolitan Sanitary District imposed regulations on factories that were identified as having large amounts of heavy metal discharge.<ref name=":0" />
On December 2, 1970 the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) was formed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.epa.gov/history|title=EPA History|last=EPA, OA|first=US|website=www.epa.gov|language=en|access-date=2016-10-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161028021903/https://www.epa.gov/history|archivedate=2016-10-28|df=}}</ref> With the formation of the EPA, the federal government had the funds and the oversight to influence major environmental changes. Following the formation of the EPA, the United States saw groundbreaking legislation such as the [[Clean Water Act]] (1972) and the [[Safe Drinking Water Act]] (1974).
The [[Federal Water Pollution Control Act]] (FWPCA) of 1948 was amended in 1972 to what is more commonly known as the [[Clean Water Act]] (CWA). The subsequent amendments provided a basis for the federal government to begin regulating pollutants, implement wastewater standards, and increase funding for water treatment facilities among other things.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.epa.gov/laws-regulations/history-clean-water-act|title=History of the Clean Water Act|last=EPA, OA, OP, ORPM, RMD|first=US|website=www.epa.gov|language=en|access-date=2016-10-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161108022914/https://www.epa.gov/laws-regulations/history-clean-water-act|archivedate=2016-11-08|df=}}</ref> Two years later, in 1974, the Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA) was passed by congress. The SDWA aimed to monitor and protect the United States drinking water, and the water sources it is drawn from.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.epa.gov/sdwa|title=Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA)|last=EPA, OW, OGWDW|first=US|website=www.epa.gov|language=en|access-date=2016-10-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027125530/https://www.epa.gov/sdwa|archivedate=2016-10-27|df=}}</ref>
As part of the SDWA, in 1991, the EPA placed chromium under its list of maximum contaminant level goals (MCLG), to have a maximum contaminant level (MCL) of 100 ppb.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://www.epa.gov/dwstandardsregulations/chromium-drinking-water#if-epa-decides-regulate|title=Chromium in Drinking Water|last=EPA, OW, OGWDW|first=US|website=www.epa.gov|language=en|access-date=2016-10-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161028022008/https://www.epa.gov/dwstandardsregulations/chromium-drinking-water#if-epa-decides-regulate|archivedate=2016-10-28|df=}}</ref> In 1996, the SDWA was amended to include a provision known as the Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Rule (UCMR).<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=https://www.epa.gov/dwucmr/third-unregulated-contaminant-monitoring-rule|title=Third Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Rule|last=EPA, OW, OGWDW|first=US|website=www.epa.gov|language=en|access-date=2016-10-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027124423/https://www.epa.gov/dwucmr/third-unregulated-contaminant-monitoring-rule|archivedate=2016-10-27|df=}}</ref> Under this rule, the EPA issues a list of 30 or less contaminants that aren’t normally regulated under the SDWA. Chromium was monitored under the third UCMR, from January 2013 through December 2015.<ref name=":8" /> The EPA uses data from these reports to assist in making regulatory decisions.
==== Current policies in the United States ==== The current EPA standard in measuring chromium, is in reference to total chromium, both trivalent and hexavalent. However, preliminary findings from water tests conducted by the [[Environmental Working Group]] (EWG), suggest that chromium is most often found in the hexavalent form; the more toxic of the two.<ref>Sutton, R. (2010, December 20). Chromium-6 in U.S. Tap Water (J. Houlihan, R. Sharp, & N. Bruzelius, Eds.). Retrieved October 10, 2016, from {{cite web |url=http://oehha.ca.gov/media/downloads/water/public-health-goal/ewg1coms.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-10-27 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161028021618/http://oehha.ca.gov/media/downloads/water/public-health-goal/ewg1coms.pdf |archivedate=2016-10-28 |df= }}</ref> Often trivalent and hexavalent chromium are mentioned together, when in fact they are very different from each other.<ref name=":7" /> This is an issue because hexavalent chromium can cause cancer, whereas trivalent chromium does not.<ref name=":7" />
In 1991, the MCL for chromium exposure was set based on potential of “adverse dermatological effects” related to long-term chromium exposure.<ref name=":7" /> Chromium’s MCL of 100 ppb has not changed since its 1991 recommendation. In 1998 the EPA released a toxicological review of hexavalent chromium.<ref name=":7" /> This report examined current literature, at the time, and came to the conclusion that chromium was associated with various health issues.<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=https://cfpub.epa.gov/ncea/iris2/chemicalLanding.cfm?substance_nmbr=144|title=Chromium(VI) CASRN 18540-29-9 {{!}} IRIS {{!}} US EPA, ORD|last=Division|first=US EPA, ORD, Integrated Risk Information System|website=cfpub.epa.gov|language=en|access-date=2016-10-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161028083633/https://cfpub.epa.gov/ncea/iris2/chemicalLanding.cfm?substance_nmbr=144|archivedate=2016-10-28|df=}}</ref>
Before the EPA can adjust the policy on chromium levels in drinking water, they have to release a final human health assessment.<ref name=":7" /> The EPA mentions two specific documents that are currently under review to determine whether or not to adjust the current drinking water standard for chromium.<ref name=":7" /> The first study the EPA mentioned that is under review is a 2008 study conducted by the Department of Health and Human Services National Toxicology Program. This study looks at chronic oral exposure of hexavalent chromium in rats, and its association with cancer. The other study mentioned is a human health assessment of chromium, titled Toxicological Review of Hexavalent Chromium. The final human health assessment is currently in the stage of draft development.<ref name=":9" /> This stage is the first of seven. The EPA gives no forecast to when the review will be finalized and if a decision will be made.
===== Military applications =====
Since World War II,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.arl.army.mil/arlreports/2004/ARL-TR-3220.pdf|title=Replacement Alternatives to the Chromate Wash Primer DOD-P-15328D|last=Smith|first=Paulette|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> the U.S. Army relied on hexavalent chromium compounds, called Cr(VI), to protect its vehicles, equipment, aviation and missile systems from corrosion. The wash primer was sprayed as a pretreatment and protective layer on bare metal.<ref name=":16">{{Cite web|url=https://www.dsiac.org/resources/news/arl-effort-improves-health-environment-bottom-line|title=ARL Effort Improves Health, Environment, Bottom Line {{!}} DSIAC|website=www.dsiac.org|language=en|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref>
From 2012-2015, [[Army Research Laboratory]] conducted research on a wash primer replacement, as a part of the DoD’s effort to eliminate the use of toxic wash primers in the military.<ref name=":16" /> Studies indicated that Cr(VI) contained hazardous air pollutants and high levels of volatile organic compounds.<ref name=":17">{{Cite web|url=https://www.arl.army.mil/www/default.cfm?article=2972|title=ARL effort improves health, environment, bottom line {{!}} U.S. Army Research Laboratory|website=www.arl.army.mil|language=en|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref>
The project resulted in ARL qualifying three wash primer alternatives in 2015<ref name=":17" /> for use on Army depots, installations and repair facilities.<ref name=":16" /> The research led to the removal of chromate products from Army facilities in 2017.<ref name=":16" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@RDECOM/arl-wins-award-improving-health-and-environment-2c3b88ae8ad9|title=ARL wins award improving health and environment|last=RDECOM|first=U. S. Army|date=2017-03-16|website=U.S. Army RDECOM|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref>
ARL’s researchers won the fiscal 2016 Secretary of the Army Award for Environmental Excellence in Weapon System Acquisition for their efforts on the wash primer replacement.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@RDECOM/arl-wins-award-improving-health-and-environment-2c3b88ae8ad9|title=ARL wins award improving health and environment|last=RDECOM|first=U. S. Army|date=2017-03-16|website=U.S. Army RDECOM|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref>
==== Pending regulations in the United States ==== In 2010, the [[Environmental Working Group]] studied the drinking water in 35 American cities. The study was the first nationwide analysis measuring the presence of the chemical in U.S. water systems. The study found measurable hexavalent chromium in the tap water of 31 of the cities sampled, with [[Norman, Oklahoma]], at the top of list; 25 cities had levels that exceeded California's proposed limits.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/greenhouse/post/2010/12/tap-water-of-many-us-cities-has-probable-carcinogen-study/1#.VkziPoREmlY|title=Study: Tap water in U.S. cities has probable carcinogen|newspaper=USATODAY.COM|access-date=2016-10-28}}</ref> The EPA currently limits total chromium in drinking water to 100 parts per billion, but there is no established specifically for chromium(VI). In the same year, the [[California Environmental Protection Agency]] had proposed a goal of 0.2 parts per billion, despite a 2001 state law requiring a standard be set by 2005. A final Public Health Goal of 0.02 ppb was established in July 2011.<ref name="Hexavalent Chromium PHG" />
As of August 2016, the EWG alongside activist [[Erin Brockovich]] is pushing for the EPA to change the nationwide MCL to be more reflective of the California standards. This response comes as result of the resignation of a top state health official in North Carolina. [[Pat McCrory|Governor Pat McCrory]] had been attempting to remove warnings against drinking water potentially contaminated by hexavalent chromium from [[Duke Energy]] coal burning facilities. The confusion on the regulating guidelines and health safety of hexavalent chromium within drinking water has led to multiple standards. The EWG's push for stricter national guidelines is done in hopes to eliminate the confusion among citizens and state officials as well as to protect the health of the population from this carcinogen.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ewg.org/release/wake-nc-hexavalent-chromium-scandal-environmentalists-call-epa-set-national-drinking-water|title=In Wake of N.C. Chrom-6 Scandal, EWG, Brockovich Call for Action by EPA|newspaper=EWG|access-date=2016-10-28|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161028084859/http://www.ewg.org/release/wake-nc-hexavalent-chromium-scandal-environmentalists-call-epa-set-national-drinking-water|archivedate=2016-10-28|df=}}</ref>
The EWG released an analysis in September 2016 of federal data from nationwide drinking water tests which showed that seventy-five percent of samples contained hexavalent chromium at levels higher than the California public health goal of 0.02 ppb. The EWG estimates that the US will see 12,000 excess cases in cancer by the end of the century if hexavalent chromium exposure in drinking water is not reduced.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ewg.org/research/chromium-six-found-in-us-tap-water|title='Erin Brockovich' Carcinogen in Tap Water of More than 200 Million Americans|newspaper=EWG|access-date=2016-10-28|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161028084953/http://www.ewg.org/research/chromium-six-found-in-us-tap-water|archivedate=2016-10-28|df=}}</ref>
====California====
===== Davenport ===== Monterey Bay Unified Air Pollution Control District monitored airborne levels of hexavalent chromium at an elementary school and fire department, as well as the point-source. They concluded that there were high levels of hexavalent chromium in the air, originating from a local cement plant, called [[Cemex]].<ref name=":11">Health Services Agency. (2008, Nov. 18). ''Air Quality Issues in the Town of Davenport''. Retrieved from: {{cite web |url=http://sccounty01.co.santa-cruz.ca.us/BDS/Govstream2/Bdsvdata/non_legacy_2.0/agendas/2008/20081118-440/PDF/058.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-10-27 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161028024004/http://sccounty01.co.santa-cruz.ca.us/BDS/Govstream2/Bdsvdata/non_legacy_2.0/agendas/2008/20081118-440/PDF/058.pdf |archivedate=2016-10-28 |df= }}</ref> The levels of hexavalent chromium were 8 to 10 times higher than the air district's acceptable level at Pacific Elementary School and the Davenport Fire Department.<ref name=":11" /> The [[Santa Cruz County, California|County of Santa Cruz]] sought help of the Health Services Agency (HSA) to investigate the findings of the Air District's report. Cemex voluntarily ceased operations due to the growing concern within the community, while additional air samples were analyzed.<ref name=":11" /> The HSA worked with Cemex to implement engineering controls, such as dust scavenging systems and other dust mitigation procedures. Cemex also made a change in the materials they used, trying to replace current materials with materials lower in chromium.<ref name=":11" /> The HSA also monitored the surrounding schools to determine if there were any health risks. Most schools came back with low levels, but in the case of higher levels a contractor was hired to clean up the chromium deposits.<ref name=":11" /> This case highlights the previously unrecognized possibility that hexavalent chromium can be released from cement-making.
===== Paramount ===== Air quality officials are taking enforcement action against two metal-processing plants they believe are contributing to hexavalent chromium emissions in [[Paramount, California]].<ref>{{Cite news | url = http://latimes.us10.list-manage2.com/track/click?u=f089ecc9238c5ee13b8e5f471&id=a7508ef0cc&e=028a1540f9 | title = Air quality agency aims to stop metal plants accused of polluting Paramount with cancer-causing emissions | date = November 29, 2016 | publisher = ''Los Angeles Times''}}</ref>
===== Hinkley ===== {{Main article|Hinkley groundwater contamination}}Hexavalent chromium was found in drinking water in the southern California town of [[Hinkley, California|Hinkley]] and was brought to popular attention by the involvement of [[Erin Brockovich]] and Attorney [[Edward Masry]]. The source of contamination was from the evaporating ponds of a PG&E ([[Pacific Gas and Electric]]) natural gas pipeline Compressor Station located approximately 2 miles southeast of Hinkley. Between 1952 and 1966, chromium(VI) was used to prevent corrosion in the cooling stacks. The wastewater was then dumped into the unlined evaporating ponds. As a result, the chromium(VI) leaked into the groundwater source.<ref name=":12" /> The 580 ppb chromium(VI) in the groundwater in Hinkley exceeded the Maximum Contaminant Level (MCL) of 100 ppb for total chromium currently set by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).<ref>[http://www.epa.gov/safewater/dwh/c-ioc/chromium.html U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Consumer Factsheet on: Chromium.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081010171348/http://www.epa.gov/safewater/dwh/c-ioc/chromium.html |date=October 10, 2008 }}</ref> It also exceeded the California MCL of 50 ppb (as of November 2008) for all types of chromium.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cdph.ca.gov/certlic/drinkingwater/Documents/DWdocuments/EPAandCDPH-11-28-2008.pdf |title=California Department of Public Health, Maximum Contaminant Levels and Regulatory Dates for Drinking Water. |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-12-05 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130718144405/http://www.cdph.ca.gov/certlic/drinkingwater/Documents/DWdocuments/EPAandCDPH-11-28-2008.pdf |archivedate=2013-07-18 |df= }}</ref> California first established an MCL specifically for hexavalent chromium in 2014, set at 10 ppb.<ref name="HEX Chrome Letter" /> Prior to that only total chromium standards applied.
A more recent study found that from 1996 to 2008, 196 cancers were identified among residents of the census tract that included Hinkley — a slightly lower number than the 224 cancers that would have been expected given its demographic characteristics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://archive.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2010/12/13/survey_shows_unremarkable_cancer_rate_in_ca_town/|title=Survey shows unremarkable cancer rate in CA town|newspaper=Boston.com|access-date=2016-10-28|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161012141515/http://archive.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2010/12/13/survey_shows_unremarkable_cancer_rate_in_ca_town/|archivedate=2016-10-12|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cancer-rates.info/ca/|title=California Cancer Registry|last=|first=|date=2013-02-05|website=|publisher=Cdph.ca.gov|accessdate=2013-12-05|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219184454/http://cancer-rates.info/ca/|archivedate=2013-12-19|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://apha.confex.com/apha/140am/webprogram/Handout/Paper255770/Hinkley%202012%20Poster.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-01-08 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005003745/https://apha.confex.com/apha/140am/webprogram/Handout/Paper255770/Hinkley%202012%20Poster.pdf |archivedate=2015-10-05 |df= }}</ref> In June 2013 [[Mother Jones (magazine)|''Mother Jones'']] published an article regarding work by the [[Center for Public Integrity]] that was critical of the study, and some others by the same researcher, John Morgan. This comes in contrast with the conclusions reached by the EPA and California’s Department of Public Health that chromium(VI) does in fact cause cancer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.motherjones.com/environment/2013/05/erin-brockovich-hinkley-california-junk-science|title=Erin Brockovich's Biggest Debunker, Debunked|last=Heath|first=David|date=June 3, 2013|website=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-07-15|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160709023256/https://www.motherjones.com/environment/2013/05/erin-brockovich-hinkley-california-junk-science|archivedate=July 9, 2016|df=}}</ref>
At the time that a PG&E background study of chromium(VI) was conducted, average chromium(VI) levels in Hinkley were recorded as 1.19 ppb with a peak of 3.09 ppb. The PG&E Topock Compressor Station averaged 7.8ppb and peaked at 31.8ppb. The California MCL standard was still at 50 ppb at the completion of this background study.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.swrcb.ca.gov/rwqcb6/water_issues/projects/pge/docs/pge_background_study_faq2.pdf |title=PG&E Background Study |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-12-05 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120723052445/http://www.swrcb.ca.gov/rwqcb6/water_issues/projects/pge/docs/pge_background_study_faq2.pdf |archivedate=2012-07-23 |df= }}</ref> In comparison, the [[Office of Environmental Health Hazard Assessment]] (OEHHA) of the California EPA, proposed a health goal of 0.06 ppb of chromium(VI) in drinking water in 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://oehha.ca.gov/water/phg/chr6draft082009.html |title=OEHHA Water - Draft PHG for Hexavalent Chromium |publisher=Oehha.ca.gov |date= |accessdate=2014-01-06 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106185238/http://oehha.ca.gov/water/phg/chr6draft082009.html |archivedate=2014-01-06 |df= }}</ref> In 2010, Erin Brockovich returned to Hinkley in the midst of claims that the plume was spreading, despite PG&E cleanup efforts.<ref>{{cite web | title=Erin Brockovich II? Activist Returns To Aid Town | author=Carrie Kahn | url=https://www.npr.org/2010/12/13/131967600/erin-brockovich-ii-activist-returns-to-aid-town | publisher=[[NPR]] | date=2010-12-13 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180112214714/https://www.npr.org/2010/12/13/131967600/erin-brockovich-ii-activist-returns-to-aid-town | archivedate=2018-01-12 | df= }}</ref> PG&E continues to provide bottled water for the residents of Hinkley as well as offer to buy their homes. All other ongoing cleanup documentation is maintained at California EPA's page.<ref name=":12">{{cite web |url=http://www.swrcb.ca.gov/rwqcb6/water_issues/projects/pge/index.shtml |title=Lahontan Regional Water Quality Control Board |publisher=Swrcb.ca.gov |date= |accessdate=2014-01-06 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106185617/http://www.swrcb.ca.gov/rwqcb6/water_issues/projects/pge/index.shtml |archivedate=2014-01-06 |df= }}</ref>
==== Illinois ==== In [[Chicago]]'s first ever testing for the toxic metal contaminant, results show that the city's local drinking water contains levels of hexavalent chromium more than 11 times higher than the health standard set in California in July 2011. The results of the test showed that the water which is sent to over 7 million residents had average levels of 0.23 ppb of the toxic metal. California's Office of Environmental Health Hazard Assessment designated the nation's new "public health goal" limit as 0.02 ppb. Echoing their counterparts in other cities where the metal has been detected, Chicago officials stress that local tap water is safe and suggest that if a national limit is adopted, it likely would be less stringent than California's goal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcchicago.com/news/health/chicago-water-chromium-127068203.html#ixzz1UNwMlC6Q|title=Toxic Metal Found in Chicago Drinking Water|last=Rodriguez|first=Robert|date=2011-08-06|publisher=NBC Chicago|accessdate=2013-08-18|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130216072838/http://www.nbcchicago.com/news/health/chicago-water-chromium-127068203.html#ixzz1UNwMlC6Q|archivedate=2013-02-16|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/health/ct-met-drinking-water-chromium-20110806,0,5813267.story |title=Toxic chromium found in Chicago drinking water |last=Hawthorne |first=Michael |work=Chicago Tribune |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807014854/http://www.chicagotribune.com/health/ct-met-drinking-water-chromium-20110806%2C0%2C5813267.story |archivedate=August 7, 2011 |df= }}</ref> The [[Illinois Environmental Protection Agency]] (Illinois EPA) has developed a chromium(VI) strategic plan which outlines tasks in order to reduce the levels of chromium(VI) in Illinois' drinking water. One of which is to work with the U.S. EPA to provide significant technical assistance to the City of Chicago to ensure they quickly develop an effective chromium(VI) specific monitoring program that makes use of the U.S. EPA-approved methods.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.epa.state.il.us/water/compliance/drinking-water/publications/chromium-strategy.pdf|title=Water compliance: Chromium strategy|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027055918/http://www.epa.state.il.us/water/compliance/drinking-water/publications/chromium-strategy.pdf|archivedate=2016-10-27|df=}}</ref>
====Massachusetts==== Cambridge Plating Company, now known as Purecoat North, was an electroplating business in [[Belmont, Massachusetts]]. A report was conducted by the [[Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry]] (ATSDR), to evaluate the association between environmental exposures from the Cambridge Plating Company and health effects on the surrounding community. The report indicated that residents of Belmont were exposed to chromium via air emissions, as well as groundwater and soil.<ref name=":10">Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, Public Health Assessment for Cambridge Plating Company. (2007, Dec. 17). ''Evaluation of Environmental Concerns and Cancer Incidence in Belmont and Surrounding Communities.'' Retrieved from {{cite web |url=http://www.mass.gov/eohhs/docs/dph/environmental/investigations/belmont/cambridge-plating-company-report.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-03-20 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120917122923/http://www.mass.gov/eohhs/docs/dph/environmental/investigations/belmont/cambridge-plating-company-report.pdf |archivedate=2012-09-17 |df= }}</ref> However, six types of cancer were evaluated, and the incidence was actually found to be average, in most cases, across all types, if not a little bit lower than average.<ref name=":10" /> For example, in kidney cancer the number of observed cases was 7 versus an expected 16.<ref name=":10" /> While that was the case for most diseases, it was not for all. The incidence of leukemia among females was elevated in Belmont, MA during 1982–1999 (32 diagnoses observed vs. 23.2 expected).<ref name=":10" /> Elevations in females were due to four excess cases in each time period (11 diagnoses observed vs. 6.9 expected during 1988–1993; 13 diagnoses observed vs. 8.7 expected during 1994–1999) while elevations among males were based on one to three excess cases.<ref name=":10" /> ATSDR deemed Cambridge Plating as an Indeterminate Public Health Hazard in the past, but No Apparent Public Health Hazard in the present or future.<ref name=":10" />
==== Missouri ==== In 2009, a lawsuit was filed against Prime Tanning Corporation of [[St. Joseph, Missouri]], over alleged hexavalent chromium contamination in [[Cameron, Missouri]]. A cluster of brain tumors had developed in the town that was above average for the population size of the town. The lawsuit alleges that the tumors were caused by waste hexavalent chromium that had been distributed to local farmers as free fertilizer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aboutlawsuits.com/lawsuit-alleges-cameron-missouri-brain-tumors-linked-to-fertilizer-3690/|title=Lawsuit Alleges Cameron Missouri Brain Tumors Linked to Fertilizer|date=2009-04-28|publisher=AboutLawsuits.com|accessdate=2013-08-18|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130621215524/http://www.aboutlawsuits.com/lawsuit-alleges-cameron-missouri-brain-tumors-linked-to-fertilizer-3690/|archivedate=2013-06-21|df=}}</ref> In 2010 a government study found hexavalent chromium within the soil but not at levels that were hazardous to human health. In 2012, the case ruled that $10 million would be distributed to over a dozen farmers affected in the northwest Missouri area. The Tanning Corporation still denies that their fertilizer caused any harm. Some residents claim that the tumors were a direct cause from the chromium exposure, but it is difficult to determine what other future impacts might arise from exposure in the specific Missouri counties.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/article301330/Burns--McDonnell-settles-case-alleging-hazardous-sludge.html|title=Burns & McDonnell settles case alleging hazardous sludge|first=|date=March 12, 2012|website=www.kansascity.com|publisher=The Kansas City Star|access-date=October 10, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027130004/http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/article301330/Burns--McDonnell-settles-case-alleging-hazardous-sludge.html|archivedate=October 27, 2016|df=}}</ref>
==== Texas ==== On April 8, 2009, the [[Texas Commission on Environmental Quality]] (TCEQ) collected ground water samples from a domestic well on West County Road 112 in [[Midland, Texas]] (U.S.), in response to a resident complaint of yellow water. The well was found to be contaminated with chromium(VI). The Midland groundwater reached higher levels of contamination than the EPA mandated maximum contaminant level (MCL) of 100 parts per billion. The current groundwater plume of chromium lies under approximately 260 acres of land at the West County Road 112 Groundwater Site. In response, the TCEQ installed filtration systems on water-well sites that showed contamination of chromium.<ref name=":13">{{Cite web|url=https://www.tceq.texas.gov/remediation/sites/cr112.html|title=West County Road 112, Midland, TX|website=www.tceq.texas.gov|access-date=2016-10-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161028083815/https://www.tceq.texas.gov/remediation/sites/cr112.html|archivedate=2016-10-28|df=}}</ref>
As of 2016, TCEQ had sampled water from 235 wells and has installed over 45 anion-exchange filtration systems from this site<ref name=":13" /> determined to be centered at 2601 West County Road 112, Midland, Texas.<ref name=":14">{{Cite web|url=https://cumulis.epa.gov/supercpad/CurSites/dsp_ssppSiteData1.cfm?id=0606992|title=Search Superfund Site Information|last=OSRTI|first=US EPA,|website=cumulis.epa.gov|language=en|access-date=2016-10-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170131130939/https://cumulis.epa.gov/supercpad/cursites/dsp_ssppSiteData1.cfm?id=0606992|archivedate=2017-01-31|df=}}</ref> The TCEQ continues to sample wells surrounding the area to monitor the movement of the plume. In addition, they continue to monitor the effectiveness of the anion-exchange filtration systems by sampling on a year-quarterly and the filters are maintained at no cost to the residents.
As of March 2011, the West County Road 112 Ground Water site was added to the [[National Priorities List]] (NPL) also known as the Superfund List by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).<ref name=":13" /> From 2011 to 2013, TCEQ installed groundwater monitors and conducted groundwater sampling. In 2013, TCEQ began sampling residential soil and confirmed that it was contaminated from use of the contaminated groundwater for garden and lawn care.
According to the EPA, ongoing investigations have not concluded the source of the contamination and cleanup solutions are still being developed. Until such investigations are complete and remediation established, residents will continue to be at risk for health effects from exposure to the groundwater contamination.<ref name=":14" />
==== Wisconsin ==== On January 7, 2011 it was announced that [[Milwaukee|Milwaukee, Wisconsin]] had tested its water and hexavalent chromium was found to be present. Officials stated that it was in such small quantities that it was nothing to worry about, although this contaminant is a carcinogen. In Wisconsin, Milwaukee's average chromium(VI) level is 0.194 parts per billion (the EPA recommended maximum contaminant level (MCL) is 100 ppb).<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":15" /> All 13 water systems tested positive for chromium(VI). Four out of seven systems detected the chemical in [[Waukesha County, Wisconsin|Waukesha County]], and both [[Racine County, Wisconsin|Racine]] and [[Kenosha County, Wisconsin|Kenosha Counties]] had the highest levels averaging more than 0.2 parts per billion.<ref name=":15">{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbs58.com/story/33146644/dangerous-levels-of-erin-brockovich-chemical-found-in-local-drinking-water|title=Dangerous Levels of 'Erin Brockovich' Chemical Found in Local Drinking Water|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027055407/http://www.cbs58.com/story/33146644/dangerous-levels-of-erin-brockovich-chemical-found-in-local-drinking-water|archivedate=2016-10-27|df=}}</ref> Further testing was being conducted as of 2011.<ref>[http://www.jsonline.com/news/milwaukee/113101749.html City defends water safety] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110110171236/http://www.jsonline.com/news/milwaukee/113101749.html |date=2011-01-10 }} ''Milwaukee Wisconsin Journal Sentinel'', January 7, 2011</ref> There was no further information available as of October 2016.
==See also== *[[California Proposition 65 (1986)]]

Economou-Eliopoulos, D. Antivachi, Ch. Vasilatos and Megremi, I. | doi = 10.1016/j.gsf.2011.11.010 | volume=3 | issue= 4 | journal=Geoscience Frontiers | pages=523–539| year= 2012 }}
